Posts.Content: Fairwind, thanks very much. Your reply is very helpful. Thanks for sharing your experiences. I hope to be looking back in a year with PSA almost 0, etc. I note your PSA has climbed to 1.1 now; what HT etc are you taking now?
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: I am scheduled for Da Vinci in Aug/Sept followed by radiation for advanced local prostate cancer ( Gleason 4 + 3, all 12 biopsy samples positive) At the time of scheduling on 16 May, my PSA was 34 and I started Casodex bicalutamide 150mg per day. My PSA last week was 14... Should it be lower?
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Today I got PSA results back from a test last week. My PSA has gone up to 19.8... Is this normal?
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Today I got PSA results back from a test last week. My PSA has gone up to 19.8... Is this normal?
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Donelson, when dealing with prostate cancer, there is no such thing as "normal"....Every case is different. Have you read Dr. Walsh's book? I would be questioning your surgeon about whether surgery is the most appropriate, effective treatment at this point..It may very well be that surgery + radiation + hormone treatment is your best course of treatment, your best shot at a cure, but it also subjects you to the heaviest possible side-effect load....Have you consulted with a Radiation Oncologist and Medical Oncologist and heard their opinions on how you should proceed? Thanks very much. Yes, talked with both surgeon and radiation oncologist. My feeling is that my prostate and seminal vesicles are a reservoir of cancerous cells, any of which may decide at some point to mutate into metastasis. If all those cells are removed from me, then I am not at risk from them after removal. After discussion they both agreed. I also have a friend in the UK who was diagnosed almost identically to me (everyone is different yes) and had both surgery and radiation and is doing well without serious side effects, other than the usual short term mostly. What I am worried about is the jump in my PSA while on Casodex...

Posts.Content: PSA 25-27 My Gleason score has been reduced to 7 from 9 out of 10. Very good. Bad is seminal vesicles heavily involved. Update 16 May. Choline F-18 PET scan last week shows surgery possible and the surgeon agrees this is best initial course. Now on casodex (bicalutamide) to shrink prostate & seminal areas before surgery in August. This drug also stops mostly the growth of the cancer I am told. Radiation to follow late 2013. ---- Question, how long does it take for the bicalutamide (Casodex) to become fully effective at stopping cancer growth?
Posts.Title: Update & bicalutamide (Casodex) question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH ... Gleason score has been reduced from 9 to 7... Thanks very much, Chuck. It is a 4+3 Gleason, and a great relief from the 5+4 I had before, although all 12 samples had 12mm of cancer tissue in them. I am classed as T3bN0M0 right now. Dr Chris Ogden will be doing the surgery (1,300 or so DaVinci ops) - very very skilled and bright. I very much enjoyed talking to him about "theory". He is interested in a study of prostatectomy PLUS radiation for advanced cases, but such a study would take time to organise. He was happy with the Choline F-18 scan, and will remove the lot. Then mop up with radiation sometime after. Waiting until August does make me a bit nervous. I have read that sometimes, some small number of men don't respond to Casodex, so I will ask for a test of testosterone levels in a month or so. Right now I can still get erections etc. Good luck to you, Chuck, and thanks again for your support. William
Posts.Title: Update & bicalutamide (Casodex) question

Posts.Content: Thanks, all !
Posts.Signature: Initial PSA 24 in Oct 2012 Highest PSA 37 in April 2013, then Casodex 150mg per day before surgery PSA 14 in July 2013 PSA 20 in Aug 2013 PSA 10 in Oct 2013 Gleason 5+4 orig, later reduced to 4+3. All 12 cores cancer MRI, Bone PET scan, Soft-tissue PET scan spring 2013 Locally advanced, appears limited to prostate and seminal vesicles Second bone PET scan late Sept 2013, surgery 7 Nov 2013 I hope Schedule for Da Vinci surgery 7 Nov 2013, then radiation to mop up later

Posts.Content: "Most clinicians have felt that 'more was better' when it came to blocking testosterone in prostate cancer patients, however, results for the specific endpoints we focused on, OS and DSS, indicate that this was clearly not the case," said Amin Mirhadi, MD, lead author of the study and a radiation oncologist at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. "This data supports administering less treatment, which will result in fewer side effects and reduce patients' overall health care costs." Report Here
Posts.Title: Study: Blocking testosterone in prostate cancer patients; more is not better

Posts.Content: I had my DaVinci 7 days ago (7 Nov), and all went well according to surgeon. I was put on Laxatives in the hospital immediately, and mostly only had liquid diet, very few solids. I have been eating more soups and Bran cereal 3x per day since Monday 11 Nov. Nothing seems to work though, and the bloat and pain is getting more severe every day. I also walked Mon & Tues for 45 mins each, and I am about to go walk today as well. Still taking the laxative. Should I ask for enema or some such?
Posts.Signature: Initial PSA 24 in Oct 2012 Highest PSA 37 in April 2013, then Casodex 150mg per day before surgery PSA 14 in July 2013 PSA 20 in Aug 2013 PSA 10 in Oct 2013 Gleason 5+4 orig, later reduced to 4+3. All 12 cores cancer MRI, Bone PET scan, Soft-tissue PET scan spring 2013 Locally advanced, appears limited to prostate and seminal vesicles Second bone PET scan late Sept 2013, surgery 7 Nov 2013 I hope Schedule for Da Vinci surgery 7 Nov 2013, then radiation to mop up later
Posts.Title: Constipation getting worse after DaVinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter Down graded from G9 to G8 is a big deal. Seminal Vesicle involvement is still classified as localized and the survival statistics are not that different from organ confined. You should be OK with your treatment protocol. Best of luck to you. Thanks! G7 in fact! Had a flourine-18 choline PET today. Will get results on 16th. If good, then surgery, then radiation. Hormones casodex will start tomorrow. Good luck to you too!
Posts.Title: update; biopsy downgraded from 5+4 to 4+3 (hurray), but spread to seminal vesicles

Posts.Content: Having choline P.E.T. scan Thursday 9th. Have spoken to surgeon and radio-oncologist - Plan is tentatively to have DaVinci, then radiation, and hormone treatments - the kitchen sink. I have been telling friends: They have this amazing gun, huge. Then they take all this cool shit, load it into a kitchen sink, and fire it at my groin. After the choline PET scan tomorrow, I will start bicalutamide... 1. What have been your experiences with that? 2. This article looks VERY interesting; statins to reduce cancer mortality http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0502093510.htm 3. Another article about statins and radiation treatment http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases...0323104727.htm Good luck to all William
Posts.Title: update; biopsy downgraded from 5+4 to 4+3 (hurray), but spread to seminal vesicles

Posts.Content: I had meeting at hospital today. Xmas time I had PSA of 33, now at 25 = about the same. No sudden jump though MRI shows clear mass inside prostate, without lymph nodes involved. No real symptoms yet; can pee okay, no pain, no blood. Had green light laser surgery 8 yrs ago to open up urethra due to swollen prostate; that seems fine still. Bone scan and biopsy to be done within 2 weeks. I feel fine, but a bit stressed. Good luck to you all. William
Posts.Title: MRI shows lump 1/5th size of prostate, PSA was 33, now 25, bone scan and biopsy soon

Posts.Content: Xmas PSA 33. Three weeks ago 25. The only other PSAs I know are 18 months ago = 4, and 8 years ago = 3.5 Thanks very much for your advice and support. I am not afraid to have a full RP. - Done having kids etc. What are the RP options? Are any methods clearly superior?

Posts.Title: MRI shows lump 1/5th size of prostate, PSA was 33, now 25, bone scan and biopsy soon

Posts.Content: They indicated to me today that RP is done at the Royal Marsden hospital. I checked and happily found this: http://www.royalmarsden.nhs.uk/diagn...e-surgery.aspx "The Royal Marsden has performed more robotic surgical procedures for prostate cancer than any other hospital in the UK. In 2011, Mr Chris Ogden, a Consultant Surgeon at The Royal Marsden, was presented with the Intuitive Surgical UK Innovation Award after reaching the major milestone of 1,000 procedures. He is the first surgeon in the UK and only the fourth in Europe to achieve this. He is also the first surgeon in the UK to peer present his outcomes at the British Urological Association Annual Meeting and he won the prize for best paper in the robotic session of the America Urological Association Annual Conference in 2010."
Posts.Title: MRI shows lump 1/5th size of prostate, PSA was 33, now 25, bone scan and biopsy soon

Posts.Content: Thanks, Chuck and Newporter! Biopsy and bone scan within 2 weeks.

Posts.Title: Modified Newcastle virus

Posts.Content: Good luck to you, mariod. I am originally from Memphis, but have been living in London mostly since 1985.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi William, Is it possible you might have misread the reports? It is generally accepted that a PSA over 100 indicates systemic disease however a PSA of 20 could be caused by a number of things, including infection. It IS true that, in the presence of PCa, the higher the PSA and the lower the free PSA, the worse the long term prognosis. That DOES NOT mean an automatic death sentence! Keep us posted and good luck! --- Dave The urologist told me of the PSA 33, then ordered the MRI. He seemed surprised it had gotten so high since the last test. My testosterone is low too, which is why I met with the endocrinologist last autumn, which led to this point. Thanks for the support and boost. Yes, I find it hard to reconcile the high PSA with my feeling pretty good for 60 years old. If this has been cooking along at low levels for 10 years now, how fast could it metastasise? At one point, they thought I had a pituitary tumour to account for the low testosterone (9-10 I seem to remember), but the brain MRI last December was clear. Good luck to you, too, Dave.

AgeInfo.Phrase: my feeling pretty good for 60 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Hello all. New here. PSA 33, no real symptoms yet except insomnia perhaps...

Posts.Content: Hello, all. Sorry to meet you under these circumstances. I am originally from Memphis, but have been living in London mostly since 1985. Thank god for the National Health Service here. PSA Level was 4 about 18 months ago. Last December PSA was 33. It's being checked again. I had a prostate MRI scan today, should have results back in 2-3 weeks (sooner, but only will get them through Urologist) Not sure what to think, since I feel fine mostly; no pain or bleeding, urination not bad (although had Green Light Laser surgery to open up urethra in late 2004, which was great). I have been friends with a 32 yr old woman who has terminal small cell lung cancer, sending her money now and then for meds when she can't work (USA health system requires cash, sadly) I guess you all ask the first question: How long do I have? And the second: How bad will it be? I am not religious at all, but I do wish you all the best. William

AgeInfo.Phrase: have been friends with a 32 yr old woman who has

Posts.Title: Hello all. New here. PSA 33, no real symptoms yet except insomnia perhaps...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter You did not mentioned if your doctor ruled out prostatitis or inflammation? PSA could spike due to infection. Did your doctor give you an antibiotic treatment after the high PSA to rule it out? No, but that is a good idea, and a hope. Thanks! Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Good point newporter, William, I am also wondering about your previous urination problem. Did the doctor, after performing a DRE, ever say that your prostate was enlarged? This is a classic reason for having some urination troubles. The key here is that an enlarged prostate pushes up the PSA reading because PSA is generated by prostate tissue. Hence, the more prostate tissue (as with enlargement), the higher the PSA. Although your PSA is pretty high at 33, at least some of this could be attributed to an enlargement. Also, if you rode a bike, had sex within that 48-72 hour period before the PSA test, it must might be enough to boost it to 33. So it could be that a case of BPH, combined with the aforementioned activity within 2-3 days prior to the blood test, could account for the PSA. Your PSA of around 4 in your early 50s was also a bit high, so it very likely was an enlargement that the green laser was used to treat. It kind of all connects and hopefully means there is no prostate cancer present. Also, a PSA over 20 does not necessarily mean the cancer (if any) has spread. If you have a biopsy soon, the situation will hopefully be made clearer. Regarding a biopsy, if possible try to make sure that it is with a highly experienced urologist who has done many of them in the past. Also you would want to ensure that the urologist uses a numbing jell before inserting the probe and then injects a local anesthetic before taking the samples. Makes for a pain-free experience. Good luck! Chuck As regards DRE, I have had a few, and none have shown lumps or other problems. "Some enlargment" in 2004 when I was having trouble urinating. The laser surgery fixed that in August of 2005 and although my flow is reduced from that, it has not been reduced to discomfort, or getting up in the night more than once. And I have increased liquid intake (choc milk mostly, boy inside here. And can't have cranberry juice anymore due to kidney stones troubles ) As regards biopsy; thanks for the advice, and for the hope. Question: --> Will the MRI show the cancer nodules etc? Can it miss those? W

AgeInfo.Phrase: around 4 in your early 50s was also a bit high

Posts.Title: Hello all. New here. PSA 33, no real symptoms yet except insomnia perhaps...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sorry you have to wait several weeks for the MRI results. In the states, it usually takes only a few days. Take care, Chuck Thanks, Chuck. Your interest and support means a lot to me. 60 years old now. 1. The MRI scans were ready in 20 mins, etc etc, but the Urologist had to delay my appointment by a week. For these tests, they allow 2 weeks for an appointment for the doc to review the results, and to have a 2nd opinion, oncologist etc etc. Not keen on waiting 3 weeks though. 2. DRE- yes, he did one in Feb. 3. I had no sex for more than 24 hours before last PSA test. I was aware of that. Not 48 though. I was told it might bump the results up a few points, but certainly not to 33. 4. I had a PSA about 18 months ago (?) and it was 4. Eight years ago it was 3.7 then back to 3.2 when I was 52. The urologist noted this was a bit high for my age then 52. 5. I do ride my bike as well, but not for long rides this winter much. Maybe 5-10 mins at most. 6. No biopsy yet. 7. I don't really have urination problems now, but it's not quite as free flowing as it was after the green light laser hole drilling in late 2004. 8. No blood, no pain, etc. I started serious insomnia pretty suddenly during the early autumn last year, not sure why. Also put on 25 lbs in 4-5 months, strange. I saw some reports that said 100% of PSA's over 20 were metastasised. Ugh, that's my main worry now. Again, thanks. William

AgeInfo.Phrase: points  but certainly not to 33  4  I had a PSA

Posts.Title: Hello all. New here. PSA 33, no real symptoms yet except insomnia perhaps...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sorry you have to wait several weeks for the MRI results. In the states, it usually takes only a few days. Take care, Chuck Thanks, Chuck. Your interest and support means a lot to me. 60 years old now. 1. The MRI scans were ready in 20 mins, etc etc, but the Urologist had to delay my appointment by a week. For these tests, they allow 2 weeks for an appointment for the doc to review the results, and to have a 2nd opinion, oncologist etc etc. Not keen on waiting 3 weeks though. 2. DRE- yes, he did one in Feb. 3. I had no sex for more than 24 hours before last PSA test. I was aware of that. Not 48 though. I was told it might bump the results up a few points, but certainly not to 33. 4. I had a PSA about 18 months ago (?) and it was 4. Eight years ago it was 3.7 then back to 3.2 when I was 52. The urologist noted this was a bit high for my age then 52. 5. I do ride my bike as well, but not for long rides this winter much. Maybe 5-10 mins at most. 6. No biopsy yet. 7. I don't really have urination problems now, but it's not quite as free flowing as it was after the green light laser hole drilling in late 2004. 8. No blood, no pain, etc. I started serious insomnia pretty suddenly during the early autumn last year, not sure why. Also put on 25 lbs in 4-5 months, strange. I saw some reports that said 100% of PSA's over 20 were metastasised. Ugh, that's my main worry now. Again, thanks. William

AgeInfo.Phrase: points  but certainly not to 33  4  I had a PSA

Posts.Title: Hello all. New here. PSA 33, no real symptoms yet except insomnia perhaps...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter You did not mentioned if your doctor ruled out prostatitis or inflammation? PSA could spike due to infection. Did your doctor give you an antibiotic treatment after the high PSA to rule it out? No, but that is a good idea, and a hope. Thanks! Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Good point newporter, William, I am also wondering about your previous urination problem. Did the doctor, after performing a DRE, ever say that your prostate was enlarged? This is a classic reason for having some urination troubles. The key here is that an enlarged prostate pushes up the PSA reading because PSA is generated by prostate tissue. Hence, the more prostate tissue (as with enlargement), the higher the PSA. Although your PSA is pretty high at 33, at least some of this could be attributed to an enlargement. Also, if you rode a bike, had sex within that 48-72 hour period before the PSA test, it must might be enough to boost it to 33. So it could be that a case of BPH, combined with the aforementioned activity within 2-3 days prior to the blood test, could account for the PSA. Your PSA of around 4 in your early 50s was also a bit high, so it very likely was an enlargement that the green laser was used to treat. It kind of all connects and hopefully means there is no prostate cancer present. Also, a PSA over 20 does not necessarily mean the cancer (if any) has spread. If you have a biopsy soon, the situation will hopefully be made clearer. Regarding a biopsy, if possible try to make sure that it is with a highly experienced urologist who has done many of them in the past. Also you would want to ensure that the urologist uses a numbing jell before inserting the probe and then injects a local anesthetic before taking the samples. Makes for a pain-free experience. Good luck! Chuck As regards DRE, I have had a few, and none have shown lumps or other problems. "Some enlargment" in 2004 when I was having trouble urinating. The laser surgery fixed that in August of 2005 and although my flow is reduced from that, it has not been reduced to discomfort, or getting up in the night more than once. And I have increased liquid intake (choc milk mostly, boy inside here. And can't have cranberry juice anymore due to kidney stones troubles ) As regards biopsy; thanks for the advice, and for the hope. Question: --> Will the MRI show the cancer nodules etc? Can it miss those? W

AgeInfo.Phrase: around 4 in your early 50s was also a bit high

Posts.Content: Good luck with your meds. Hang on, more new treatments coming all the time.
Posts.Title: What does bone pain feel like

Posts.Content: "the safe anti-malarial drug chloroquine, an inhibitor of autophagy, dramatically increased cell death after androgen deprivation or bicalutamide treatment." This is an in vitro study, but if you were going to Africa some places they would give you Chloroquine regardless of prostate cancer. Personally, I will be taking this when Casodex begins to fail. Bicalutamide and Chloroquine study "Taken together, our data suggest that autophagy is a protective mechanism against androgen deprivation in HRPCa cells and that chloroquine could restore hormone dependence. This set of data could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategy against HRPCa." Comments and discussion would be much appreciated...

Posts.Title: Gleason 5+4, bone scan clear, PSA 27, MRI shows tumour confined to prostate...

Posts.Content: Hello all, and thank you. Yes, I am concerned about the high PSA. I guess I will have to wait until 2nd May to get some straight answers - I think the Urologist and Cancer Nurse are probably having trouble expressing their opinions, deferring to the higher skill/knowledge of the surgeons etc. With the high PSA and the Gleason 9, my feelings of being able to beat this for "15 years" are drastically reduced. I am in the UK, not sure about Sand Lake Imaging techniques... It seems that we should get the prostate removed in any case, to reduce the load if more metastasis occurs. I worry a bit about hormone deprivation, but only as it might affect my ability to work. For me, no work = no pay. Mostly I do programming, sitting in front of a computer, etc. Sometimes I need to go out into the field for a few days of photography. Since I am done with kids, and living is a bit higher score than having sex for me, I am willing to do whatever is available (radiation, seed, DaVinci, HDT) to extend my life as long as the quality/pain is not bad. Reading the internet and here, its hard for me to gain an idea of how long I probably can survive with reasonable quality. (Of course, the longer you can go, the higher the chance that a radical new medical technology will come along)
Posts.Title: Gleason 5+4, bone scan clear, PSA 27, MRI shows tumour confined to prostate...

Posts.Content: Not panicking, just asking: With Gleason 9, how much delay before treatment? Will hormone treatment slow Gleason 9 cancer? Or is it unaffected by removing testosterone? Is DaVinci not wise for Gleason 9? Thanks to all.
